body: It was three years ago that Freddy's clothing store settled into a former meat market on 125th Street in Harlem, and began selling discounted men's and boys' wear. Its immediate neighbor was the Record Shack, which had been in place for 17 years offering used 45's and old gospel albums, and whose lease was encased within Freddy's lease. Almost the
title: DEATH ON 125th STREET: The Dispute;From a Quiet Beginning, a Volatile Brew Explodes in Harlem

body: During the last two decades, the Record Shack on West 125th Street became a neighborhood institution, the place to go in Harlem for calypso music, old-time gospel recordings and jazz 45's. But several months ago, the owner, Sikhulu Shange, learned of plans to evict him from his storefront, and he fought back. Making it clear that he considered
title: DEATH ON 128TH STREET: THE DISPUTE;Plans to Evict Record-Shop Owner Roiled Residents

body: He had glossy brochures depicting neat two-family houses. He had samples of the building materials that would be used and the lighting fixtures that would be installed. What John Erglis did not have, he admitted in court yesterday, were nearly enough sites for the number of houses he had promised to build in the East New York section of Brooklyn
title: He Built Their Hopes but Little Else

body: ON a clear day on the bay side of Belle Harbor, you can see Manhattan. On cloudy days, the skyline is a gray blur rising from the water, giving justa hint that Belle Harbor belongs to New York City. Celeste Pacifico, her husband, Fernando, and their two children, Michael and Jessica, moved to Belle Harbor from Gravesend, Brooklyn, seven years ago.
title: The Battle of Belle Harbor

body: A steady rain speckled the Narrows as the Heaven, a 22 1/2-foot fishing boat, cut its engine and bobbed under the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge. Gene Ritter and Pete Oliver squeezed into their diving suits, strapped on scuba tanks and jumped into the murky water. "You never know what you're going to find down there," Mr. Ritter said before disappearing
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN WATERFRONT;Explorers of Watery Wilds Dive for Urban History . . .

body: IF THE directors of the Passage Theater had dreamed up a show, it could have been "Avenue X." As if custom-made for the company in setting, size and theme, the musical should establish a recurring residency here. "Keep coming back," I'd say, "till you get it right." Actually, at this stage, "Avenue X" is more than halfway right. What's right about
title: THEATER REVIEWS;Seeking Racial Harmony in the Musical Kind

body: At Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn, one physician is now responsible for the care of all 60 patients in two of the hospital's general medical wards each night from 8 P.M. to 6 A.M. Doctors consider that a nearly impossible task; until recently, five doctors, including several residents, covered the shift. At Joseph Pulitzer Intermediate School in
title: SHRINKING THE CITY: Sector by sector;How New Yorkers Feel Budget Squeeze

body: Candido Rivera was reluctant to leave the comfort of the one-bedroom apartment in Brooklyn where he had been house-sitting for a hospitalized friend, the police said yesterday, because he had no place to go. He sought revenge when he was told to leave, removing a gas stove from the apartment on Friday and selling it for $40 to a man on the street,
title: Suspect Held In Gas Blast At Project In Brooklyn

body: International 3-15 FOR U.N., FEARS AS WELL AS JOY As leaders gather to celebrate the United Nations' 50th anniversary, there are concerns that the organization that has such major functions worldwide is overextended and without clear priorities. 1 FOR MANY DIPLOMATS, NO GLITZ In the pomp of the arrival of world leaders, it may go unnoticed that
title: NEWS SUMMARY

body: When the Rev. Paul Tseng moved the Brooklyn Chinese Christian Church from Flatbush into an old American Legion hall in Sheepshead Bay seven years ago, about 30 worshipers went to his weekly Baptist services. These days more than 200 attend. "The community changed," Mr. Tseng said last week in his church, on East 15th Street and Gravesend Neck Road.
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SHEEPSHEAD BAY;New Language, and a New Life, for Avenue U

title: NEWS SUMMARY

body: A gas explosion ripped through several apartments on the top floor of a Brooklyn housing complex yesterday, injuring 20 people in a blast that officials said might have stemmed from a quarrel between a teft a maintenance worker severely burned and sent hundreds of terrified tenants of the Marlboro Houses in Coney Island fleeing into the street,
title: Exposed Stove Pipe Leads to Gas Blast That Injures 20

body: The Colonial buffs brought tri-cornered hats. Civil War types gathered maps and newspaper clippings. Neighborhood groups displayed sepia-toned, turn-of-the-century photographs. There were mementos from the 40's and 50's: badges for Steeplechase Park in Coney Island, menus and lobster bibs from Lundy's Restaurant in Sheepshead Bay, and not a few
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE;Breuckelen Revisited: A History Fair in the County of Kings

body: The Mark Twain School for the Gifted and Talented in Coney Island is a rare oasis in the public school system. The selective magnet school, which rejects three-quarters of its applicants, has among the highest math and reading scores in the city. It offers students a rigorous academic program and the opportunity to specialize in 10 "talent" areas,
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: SOUTHERN BROOKLYN; An Influx of Queens Students

body: From Bushwick to Bensonhurst, Brooklyn's 12 school districts are looking for ways to serve more students with less money. District 32 in Bushwick, which expects to gain more than 200 students this year, lost 39 teachers over the summer to an early retirement program. With the district facing a $2.5 million shortfall, Dr. Robert Brasco, the deputy
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; Schools' Bind: More Pupils, Less Money

body: The man with the puffy face and powder-blue sweatpants had become a fixture on the Steeplechase Pier, making his home on one of the few remaining relics from Coney Island's golden age. All the regulars who fish the waters below knew who he was, and many of them used to give him cigarettes and food when he came begging. On Tuesday night, four
title: Avoiding Attack, Homeless Man Leaps to Death

body: There was a surprise waiting for investigators this month when they raided the wire rooms of a major bookmaking operation in New York City. Instead of finding smoke-filled dens with the customary bookies' paraphernalia of betting slips and paper tally sheets, prosecutors said, the raiders uncovered a high-tech operation of computers, fax machines
title: Bookies Go Computer Age, But Wind Up Being Raided

body: An ex-convict from Brooklyn who was arrested on robbery charges has also been charged with a sexual assault on a 12-year-old girl in a Coney Island apartment building, a police spokeswoman said yesterday. Roland Alfred, 30, of 4725 Beach 47th Street in Sea Gate, Brooklyn, is also a suspect in a second sexual assault, of a 13-year-old girl on June
title: Ex-Convict Charged With Sexual Assault

body: Two Chinese immigrants held captive for 13 days in a Brooklyn basement closet were freed and their abductors were captured on Monday night, the police said, after an around-the-clock investigation of an international kidnapping-for-ransom plot. Kidnappings of Asians in New York by members of Asian gangs have risen in the last two years and account
title: Chinese Couple Held 13 Days In International Ransom Plot

body: The life of Gregory Scarpa Jr. reads like the script of a gangster soap opera. The latest episode unfolded yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, where Mr. Scarpa -- whom the authorities call a mobster, the son of a mobster and the nephew of a mobster -- pleaded not guilty to 13 charges including murder, racketeering, drug trafficking,
title: New Indictment for Reputed Colombo Crime Family Captain

body: The Giuliani administration plans to postpone construction of the Brooklyn Navy Yard incinerator for an additional three years and is reconsidering whether to build the plant at all, according to a draft of the city's new solid-waste management plan. The incinerator, on the drawing boards for 10 years and considered a central element in New York
title: Plan to Build Incinerator Faces Delay

body: BROWNSTONE BROOKLYN On the Waterfront Not an awful lot has actually happened there over the recent years, but the Brooklyn Heights waterfront -- or, more specifically, what to do with it -- is a perpetually, loomingly big story around the neighborhood. The reason, quite simply, is a widespread fear that development will mean losing the passionately
